The "Federal Election Standards Act of 2001" establishes the National Advisory Commission on Federal Election Standards. This commission is responsible for setting federal election standards and determining its membership. The National Advisory Commission on Federal Election Standards, established by the "Federal Election Standards Act of 2001," consists of 24 voting and 2 nonvoting members appointed by various leaders and organizations. The commission includes members appointed by the National Association of State Election Directors, local election officials appointed by different organizations, with specific representation requirements based on population size, political party, and geographic region. Appointments to the Commission shall be made within 45 days of the Act's enactment, with the initial meeting to be held within 30 days of all members being appointed. Vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment, and the Commission will establish its rules regarding quorum, meetings, voting, testimony, and additional rules as needed. SEC. 102. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission is tasked with examining and reporting on the accuracy, integrity, and efficiency of Federal election procedures in the States, developing standards for Federal elections, and making recommendations to Congress on procedural and administrative aspects of Federal elections. Specific consideration is given to certain issues in the development of standards. The Commission focuses on voter registration, ballot design, polling place accessibility, and mail-in voting procedures for Federal elections. The Commission will make recommendations to Congress on amending Federal law for conducting elections on different dates, including weekends, multiple days, and early voting options, as well as exploring the possibility of Internet voting. SEC. 103. REPORTS. The Commission will submit reports on current procedures, recommended standards, findings on election accuracy, integrity, and efficiency, as well as additional recommendations to Congress within 12 months of its initial meeting. The Commission will submit additional recommendations to Congress, and any member can submit separate views to be included in the reports. SEC. 104. POWERS. The Commission may hold hearings, receive evidence, and select locations reflecting a balance among U.S. regions. It can access federal information and use the U.S. mails. SEC. 105. COMPENSATION AND PERSONNEL. SEC. 105. COMPENSATION AND PERSONNEL. Members of the Commission serve without pay but receive travel expenses. The chair can appoint staff, request Federal employee details, and accept temporary services. Staff pay cannot exceed level V of the Executive Schedule. The Administrator of General Services will provide administrative support services to the Commission on a reimbursable basis. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting required reports. $10,000,000 is authorized for the Commission. Federal Election Standards Implementation Grants are authorized for grants. The Federal Election Commission will establish a program to make grants to qualifying States to improve Federal election procedures in accordance with recommended standards. The Commission will solicit applications from States for these grants. A "qualifying State" is defined in this section. The program will provide grants to qualifying States for improving Federal election procedures. States can use the grants for hiring employees, consultants, and procuring equipment to meet required standards. The program provides grants to States for improving Federal election procedures, including administrative support, training for officials, enhancing public confidence, and evaluating new systems. Matching funds from the grant cannot exceed 75% of total costs. The Federal Election Commission may waive the requirement for projects or activities under certain conditions. Each qualifying State must receive a minimum amount of 0.5 percent of the total grant appropriation for the fiscal year. SEC. 202. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE. The Federal Election Commission can provide technical assistance to various entities for the purposes of this title, including training centers and facilities. This assistance may involve instruction and seminars for election officials and others. SEC. 203. REPORTS TO CONGRESS.

The Federal Election Commission must submit a report to Congress within 60 days after each fiscal year detailing the programs conducted under this title and may suggest amendments to related laws. 

SEC. 204. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

$250,000,000 is authorized for the first 3 fiscal years after the enactment of this Act, with additional funds as needed for subsequent years.

TITLE III--STATE DEFINED

In this Act, "State" refers to states of the United States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, Guam, the Virgin Islands, and American Samoa.
